body:
I understand how this is working but I don't understand the need for it. Why would you have (or need) the *same* jar to be referenced in a different location? What's the actual use case here?

I guess the original Jira ticket suggests that you might be working on a fix and want to test your fix? In that case wouldn't you just run Geode out of your development tree? Or at least copy the fully built distribution to the location you need to run it from.

What if the fix affects additional jars?

@jdeppe-pivotal  

This is useful if you have two storage paths with different write permissions , one official installation, where only  sudo users  have write permissions, and GEODE_HOME is pointing to it . It can even be shared storage between multiple users on host
The other storage path has   write permissions to user, is used for PFs, that takes priority , as it comes first in class-path 
Al other jars can be given as PFs  by adding  it to user classpath without changing GEODE_HOME value except geode core . because until this fix, only  hardcoded gemfire-core-8.2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar  were able to be first . 

The only alternative for geode core PF , was to copy fully build distribution to user location, and change GEODE_HOME value.

Sai Boorlagadda wrote:
+1. The changes are neat and concise.

Although this change seems very minor I'm going to downvote it (`-1`).

It introduces an inconsistency (in how jars from the provided classpath are handled - I'd be surprised if this is actually documented anywhere). This type of quirkiness occurs throughout the product and always ends up surprising (and thus annoying) people. As Kirk alluded to, if I had seen this bit of code earlier I would have immediately assumed it to be dead and deleted it. With this change, the next developer who happens across it is going to be scratching their head and wondering what the reasoning is behind it.
Yes, I guess that is true.

@jdeppe-pivotal @igorbarc I still strongly recommend a Unit Test or Integration Test to verify the bug/fix. A UnitTest could be written directly for that method (simple Strings after all). An IntegrationTest or AcceptanceTest would be the most valuable -- if we intend to allow Users to add a jar to the front of the classpath then we should have a test that confirms it. The GfshRule would be ideal for writing an AcceptanceTest for this. Such a test would also prevent a developer from making a change that inadvertently breaks this behavior.

@jdeppe-pivotal I'm only seeing JUnit 4.12 [on Maven](http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Ca%3Ajunit%20g%3Ajunit).  Looking at the JUnit GitHub and Wiki, I believe JUnit 4.13 was never properly released.  Their [Wiki](https://github.com/junit-team/junit4/wiki) still lists it as unreleased, but the [GitHub](https://github.com/junit-team/junit4/releases) shows 4.12 as 218 commits behind `master`.

I wouldn't want to depend on a non-release library.  We could migrate to JUnit 5.x, but that'd be involved in its own right.  In the interim, I think this workaround would be good just to restore test coverage.
+1 barring fixing travis errors.
precheckin green
There is a problem causing an NPE in tests that use the start-locator property to boot up a locator.  I'm fixing that & will push another commit to the branch.
Fails rat (missing copyright notice) and spotless: once fixed, I approve of the changes.

commit cadecc24661879f097a5b09c365940fd2626a7bc (HEAD -> develop, origin/develop)
Author: Bruce Schuchardt <bschuchardt@pivotal.io>
Date:   Tue Jan 2 14:26:52 2018 -0800

    GEODE-4092 New protocol does not have an API to get the best server to connect to

    GetAllAvailableServers has been replaced by GetServer.  The handler uses
    the ServerLocator's processRequest API to ensure we have the same
    functionality as existing non-protobuf locator request handling.

    If a server isn't found we are returning Success with a null server
    location.  Should this be changed to return an error code?

Precheckin returned green after rebase, `spotlessCheck` notwithstanding.  Spotless has since been applied.

Will squash and merge after Travis completes.  Forced a push to this PR due to complications in merging `develop` rather than rebasing.

Thank you @bschuchardt for your comments,
Regarding the unit-tests you mentioned : testRemoveMemberNotCalledBeforeTimeout, testSuspectMembersNotCalledThroughPingThreadBeforeTimeout and testSuspectMembersCalledThroughSuspectThread  will not try to form a TCP connection with the suspected member.
But my changes will only come to picture when a member is trying to form TCP connection with the suspected member.

I have added a new test case for testing the doTCPcheckmember method.

I have a question regarding failure-detection ports in GMSHealthMonitor.java,
In inlineCheckIfAvailable method, there we check if failure-detection port is available or not for a particular member.
In which scenario does failure detection port of any member cannot be available ?
new commit should resolve all of your concerns. Regarding the gradle exclude, I believe gradle should handle version dependencies.
latest changes address all review comments
Precheckin running to check for potential version mismatch conflicts.
How does this affect the ability to debug the code? Does the plugin actually create the intermediate java files or just inject bytecode?
Interesting idea but I'm not sure it's worth the additional complexity.

Hey @jdeppe-pivotal,  

Generated *null*-checks are bound to the corresponding method parameter's lines, so, if you're stepping through the method call, debugger goes through them.  

*Traute* is a *javac* plugin, so, it doesn't create intermediate files but enhances the compilation in a way to insert the checks into resulting bytecode.
precheckin green
@bschuchardt @upthewaterspout Please add anyone else you think should review this change!
I've sent Jin Mei a review request since this is modifying code she put in place not that long ago.
Full precheckin passes 100% green
I've squash/merged this into develop.  Thanks @PivotalSarge for the contribution!
igorbarc, thanks for this work. I'm going to close it and create a new pull request that includes a unit test.

Some unexpected precheckin failures in translating the VM version shorthand `"000"` depending on environment.  It appears that it can be both `1.x.0-SNAPSHOT` or `0.0.0`.  Will need to adjust the test.
Kirk was working on this issue and I stepped on his toes with this PR.  I'm yanking it & will not merge to develop.

Hi Sarge,
I don't have all the context for this. Can you explain why you want to make this change?

@galen-pivotal Writing a specific, if arbitrary, port into the properties file leads to, as Dan puts it, "all of our tests run with different properties when run through gradle as when run through the IDE". It turns out that the tests were already handling the port correctly so the mcast-port property in the properties file was entirely unnecessary and possibly misleading.
Email misunderstanding - reopening
Updated the dockerfile with a new version that's appropriately licensed.
Removed current-version testing, rerunning precheckin.
Precheckin green with current-version testing removed.
Some precheckin issues that I believe were hardware hickups.  Rerunning the tasks in question.
@pdxrunner / @jdeppe-pivotal: is there anything else you want to change here?, or can we merge this one already?.
Precheckin green with await changes! Huzzah!
Rerun green.
There were a couple of committers who were strongly opposed to this change in meaning of member-timeout.  If you can sway their opinion please resubmit/reopen.

-1

I've been thinking about this PR and I don't believe it's in our best interest to merge it in.  What it would take to change my mind:

- An active community behind the project with lots of other use by well-known projects.
- A clear advantage if adopted.  Unlike kotlin, this plugin doesn't prevent NPE during coding just detects them.
- More trust about how the byte code is affected.
I think the best way to proceed with this PR is to split the changes into smaller PR's that are easier to review and merge.
LGTM. My precheckin run just finished green
Precheckin is green
This fixes an existing test(s) that fail due to event id's possibly not matching due to a race condition with client connection start up and management region putAll
Encountering problems with tests; recalling these changes until that can be sorted.

@metatype, thanks for the feedback!
A couple of notes:
1. The project is rather young and now I'm pro-actively establish the community :)
2. An advantage is that it allows detecting problems early. Consider a situation when *null* is stored in a collection within legitimate objects for further processing. Later on you get an *NPE* but there is no clue on where it came from
3. The plugin doesn't modify bytecode, it modifies *AST* built by *javac* parser. Later on the *AST* is checked by *javac* as a part of the standard compilation. Also there is an [extensive test suite|https://github.com/denis-zhdanov/traute/tree/master/core/test/src/test/java/tech/harmonysoft/oss/traute/test/suite] for multiple use-cases

@pdxrunner The test org.apache.geode.management.internal.cli.commands.ConnectCommandTest#connectUseSsl provides the coverage for `gfsh` seeking user input if any parameter is missing in ssl properties.
The changes here are to consider a default value in case if a value is not provided (which is the case for non-gfsh clients), so at the worst case a default value is also used for gfsh. But ConnectCommand prompts user for input.

@bschuchardt @kohlmu-pivotal @metatype 

Consider a Geode cluster in which some nodes contain a particular type of data which is critical to the business and hosts a large amount of data. Some nodes may host data which is not critical to the business and hosts less amount of data compared to the previous type of nodes. 

If both the type of nodes are going through  some operation which is making them unresponsive, the former type of node may take a couple of seconds extra than the later to respond.

In this scenario is it fair to give the same member-timeout to all the members?
What if we want to wait for a little longer time for such nodes.

In the present configuration in geode, we cannot wait a little longer for some nodes when compared to do this although we can configure different member-timeout for all the nodes. But i think no one will ever configure different timeouts for each node because those member-timeouts will be used to monitor their neighbors.

In this solution, we all do is wait for the suspected member-timeout instead of its own timeout during final check.
It has no backward implications also, if some one wants to use the existing behavior they will continue to use the same member-timeouts for all the nodes. So the behavior of the system is preserved.

If you have any concerns in this solution, please let me know.
thanks for fixing this. I had this failure on my precheckin
precheckin is green

@dineshpune2006, @karensmolermiller  FYI, and for anyone else interested, the output will now look like this:
```
gfsh>list members
  Name   | Id
-------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------
locator1 | 10.8.3.2(locator1:41784:locator)<ec><v0>:1024 [Coordinator]
server1  | 10.8.3.2(server1:41828)<v1>:1025
```

@jinmeiliao I'm going to dismiss your review of this docs PR.  Your code change will not appear in Geode 1.4, and this docs update specifically addresses changes that did go into 1.4.  Please re-review if you like with that in mind.

the digits. The correct ticket is GEODE-4031. I will fix the error.

precheckin green

There is a mild-mannered change in behavior here: obfuscation occurs as it should, but formatting is now consistent with the input.  The former behavior was that everything is output as a `option=value` format.

I captured the separator while iterating towards this solution.  If a consistent `option-value` is preferred, it would be a trivial update to `ArgumentRedactor:84`.

Would there be interest in using a modern eviction policy like TinyLFU? It typically has a [significantly higher hit rate](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Efficiency) than LRU by taking frequency into account. I can provide guidance on it (or alternatives like LIRS), or you could use my concurrent [implementation](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine). The concurrency technique used is described by this [HighScalability article](http://highscalability.com/blog/2016/1/25/design-of-a-modern-cache.html) and [slide deck](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1NlDxyXsUG1qlVHMl4vsUUBQfAJ2c2NsFPNPr2qymIBs).
precheckin green
precheckin green

commit aabad5f895f67c9432e2e4da0518346687188bad (HEAD -> develop, origin/develop)
Author: Bruce Schuchardt <bschuchardt@pivotal.io>
Date:   Fri Jan 19 15:09:41 2018 -0800

    GEODE-4315 Convert JSONWrapper to an interface

    JSONWrapper is now an interface.  JSONWrapperImpl is what will be returned
    by the experimental driver but it will accept anything implementing
    JSONWrapper as input.

commit 63a96d9e6512fe4ba11f2e4afe382c6977322f9f (HEAD -> develop)
Author: Bruce Schuchardt <bschuchardt@pivotal.io>
Date: Mon Jan 22 08:56:20 2018 -0800

GEODE-4317 add error handling to the experimental ProtobufDriver's Region implementation

I've added checks to ProtobufRegion for "error" responses from the server.
Along the way I found we were converting some keys to their string
representations and fixed that as well.

The exceptions thrown show the error text returned by the server. The
handling of putAll responses was already looking for errors but wasn't
including the server's message text so I changed it to do so.

This closes #1322

Currently some options allow multiple classes to be defined - we should make sure we're covering that scenario as well when parameters are included:
```
abc.xyz?{"a":1,"b":2},foo.bar?{"c":false,"d":"hotel"}
```
Double-check your current git config.  I somehow got tagged as the author of your minor fix commit.
+1 for the alias
precheckin green
precheckin is green

Yeah, besides the change in PutUserCredentials. If you don't want to miss a heartbeat whenever they say they had client/server security problem. Just leave that change out. Otherwise, everything looks good.

One more question:  if _User A_ does `gfsh deploy` and another _User B_ is issuing gfsh commands at the same time what will happen?  Will the `exportObject` cause concurrent gfsh / jmx requests to fail?
Precheckin appears to pass with this change, I'll merge this in tomorrow unless someone sees a reason not to.
what would that be different than 2 users executing any gfsh commands at the same time using different gfsh clients?

@metatype `exportObject` exports individual instances of objects (and returns those for clients to use). Thus each client will use a uniquely exported object. As an aside, the object is only exported for the lifetime of the method invocation (in this case). Once a deploy is complete, the necessary objects are unexported.
It sounds like this is making a pretty big change in the system behavior. I am surprised that there doesn't seem to be a test that's verifying that change.

IIUC, `geode-examples` has a dependency on geode that is satisfied by pulling a snapshot from maven.  Unfortunately that snapshot job is still run from jenkins and happens 1x/day.  So we don't have a good mechanism to trigger a `geode-examples` build for changes that need to pull in the latest geode commits.

Ideally, we should add a concourse job that uploads the snapshot to maven after the tests pass and before the `geode-examples` build.
@upthewaterspout Is your proposal to add a "goodbye" message to the protocol that the client sends to the server to indicate that it is safe to close the socket?

@PivotalSarge - Or maybe have different logic for the protobuf server connection? I'm not really sure if this warning is useful for the old client, but it might be there to help people notice that their clients are crashing.
@pivotal-amurmann The existing tests for jar deployment from gfsh cover this change.
precheckin is green

Although the alias is appealing, it obscures the notion that the existing option is deprecated. With multiple options we have multiple help text strings, one of which would indicate that the relevant option is 'Deprecated'. Once aliased we'd only have a single help string.

I think it's clearer to retain it as is.

@WireBaron I see your thinking. However, review of `ProtocolServerConnection` shows that its salient difference with `OriginalServerConnection` is the use of `ClientProtocolProcessor`. So I'm going to leave the name as is for now.
LGTM barring any other dev mailing list objections.
I've added GEODE-4401 to consider adding a CloseConnection message and I've pushed & closed this PR.
Two bright people don't like `ProtocolServerConnection`. I'll revisit its name.

In the interest of clarity, I've gone ahead and rerun the removal of redundant modifiers and opened them across five PRs.

See #1358 #1359 #1360 #1361 #1362
precheckin green
Changes look good.  Wondering if there was a way to modify the test to get rid of this "test-only" stat completely.  I'll merge once I confirm my precheckin etc pass for this
rebased from develop to fix integration tests due to #1355

@pivotal-amurmann Thank you for your review.
I splitted the added code out into a private method and made it easy to understand.

Hello @jhuynh1, 
Thanks for reviewing the pull request.
There's probably a way to modify the test and get rid of the `numEventsDispatched` property for sure (I thought about entirely removing it at the beginning) but, truth be told, it might be useful in the future and it doesn't represent any harm at the moment, that's why I left it.
Anyway, I can remove it if you want, just let me know.
Cheers.

@jdeppe-pivotal @PurelyApplied @sboorlagadda @pdxrunner  please review. Thanks!
@PivotalSarge I think you need to rebase on develop to get the changeset right for this. As it is now, it looks like it's capturing a bunch of cleanup commits that were merged to develop.
@galen-pivotal I did rebase from `develop`. I'll try again at some point, though, to see if another attempt alters the behavior.

I've merged the changes because the tests appear to be passing.  We should decide if the stat is useful or not and if so, add it to the stats, if not, remove it completely.  I can create a ticket for that.
